nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Pakenham, British ambassador to Luxembourg, is reading "Seeds of Change: Five Plants that Transformed Mankind" by Henry Hobhouse.. "It's a fascinating book. Each chapter is devoted to sugar, cotton, tea, or quinine, which allowed wh

nytimes_articles.headline: Evidence for Planet X Evaporates in Spotlight of New Research
nytimes_articles.abstract: ASTRONOMERS can quit looking for the elusive "Planet X" because it is not there, a new study of solar system measurements has concluded.   For a half century stargazers have hunted for Planet X, the solar system's hypothetical 10th planet. Its existence was inferred from what appeared to be irregularities in the orbital motions of several known planets. But a new study of the outer planets indicates that the long chase, based on presumed wobbles in the orbits of Uranus and Neptune caused by a planet, was based on erroneous observations and calculations.

nytimes_articles.headline: All Jordan, All Even: Chicago Takes Game 4
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was spectacular, but from Michael Jordan, the spectacular is never unexpected. Jordan was due for a performance like this, a brilliant 54-point barrage that lifted the Chicago Bulls, deflated the Knicks and dramatically changed the atmosphere of a series that New York no longer controls.   Carrying his team with a remarkable long-range shooting exhibition, Jordan led the Bulls to a series-tying 105-95 victory this afternoon at Chicago Stadium in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals. The four-of-seven-game series is tied, 2-2, heading into a crucial Game 5 confrontation Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON CONSIDERS TAX ON HOSPITALS
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is seriously considering a new tax on hospitals to help finance medical care for people who currently have no health insurance, Administration officials said today.   The officials said the proposal would be high on the agenda when Mr. Clinton meets this week with his advisers to review the design of his plan to guarantee health care for all Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rabin Shuffles His Cabinet But Critics Aren't Appeased
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a Cabinet shuffle over the weekend, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin managed to put the most serious political crisis of his year-old Government behind him.    But today he still had to contend with criticism of his leadership and the possible implications of his leadership style for the Middle East peace talks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in the Westchester Weekly section on Sunday about a directory of Jewish organizations mistated the date of a concert marking the 50th anniversary of the Hebrew Congregation of Somers. It will take place on Sunday, June 6, at 7:30 P.M. at the temple, on Mervyn Drive in Shenorock.

nytimes_articles.headline: To the Spider Woman, Broadway Is Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Chita Rivera (Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero, to be more precise) is impatient with questions about the Tony Awards on Sunday. She actually rolls her eyes and sighs when asked about whether she thinks she'll win the honors for best actress in a musical, for her title role in "Kiss of the Spider Woman."    "You delude yourself," she said on a recent afternoon at the Broadhurst Theater, in a cozy dressing room overstocked with long-stemmed red roses. "You keep telling yourself it doesn't matter, that whoever wins, that'll be just fine. Then you get there. And? It's war! If you lose, that walk out of the theater is the longest you'll ever take."

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooks Takes a Walk As Devils Jog in Place
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a disagreement with New Jersey's management over the direction the team ought to take, Herb Brooks resigned as coach yesterday after fulfilling one season of the three-year contract he was given last June 5 to "take the Devils to the next level."   Brooks, whose team (40-37-7) tied the Islanders for third place in the Patrick Division but was eliminated in five games by Pittsburgh in the first round of the playoffs, wanted the Devils to, in effect, take a step backward before going forward. The 55-year-old coach viewed youth and speed as the main ingredients for building success. Management felt the players on the team were good enough to become Stanley Cup contenders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Purity, Pederasty And a Fallen Heroine
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the morning of April 2, in the courthouse of the small northern California mining town of Jamestown, a preliminary hearing was under way on charges against Daniel Driver for allegedly molesting several young boys. During the proceedings, the mother of one of the boys, Ellie Nesler, thought she detected Mr. Driver smirking. So she went and got a gun, walked back into court and stopped the smirks forever. Now charged with murder, Ellie Nesler, cast by the law as a killer, has made herself available for the role of cultural heroine.   Ellie Nesler took us at our word. Believing that Mr. Driver was a pederast, she did what society wants done to pederasts: she plugged him five times, stopping perversion dead in its tracks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Today the Questions Are About the Knicks
nytimes_articles.abstract: They had created questions, serious questions, about the two-time defending champions. They had occasionally made Michael Jordan appear ordinary.   The Knicks came here with the chance to make their Eastern Conference championship series with the Chicago Bulls a short one. But when it was time for them to return to New York, escorted to the exit stairwell amid the delirious noise of Chicago Stadium, that chance had vanished and their hopes of advancing to the National Basketball Association finals were threatened.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yanks and Perez Get A Picnic on the Grass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Melido Perez is not used to this feeling. He knows what it's like to pitch with no runs in his favor. He knows what it's like to pitch out of a hole. But pitching with a lead -- a big lead -- is a new thing for him.   Perez did not expect the Yankees to provide him with eight runs yesterday afternoon at the Stadium. Usually, he's lucky to get three. And with Bernie Williams, Don Mattingly and Danny Tartabull on the disabled list, the Yankee offense should be suffering, not racking up the hits.

wiki_events.headline: Dobrinja mortar attack: Thirteen are killed and 133 wounded when Serb mortar shells are fired at a soccer game in Dobrinja, west of Sarajevo.

pages.title: Dobrinja mortar attack
pages.description: 1993 massacre of Bosnian civilians in Sarajevo
pages.abstract: The Dobrinja mortar attack was a massacre which occurred at 10:20 a.m. on 1 June 1993, in Dobrinja, a suburb west of Sarajevo in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Two mortar rounds were fired from Serb-held positions, hitting a football pitch where youths put on an impromptu game on the first day of the Muslim holiday Kurban Bajram. Approximately 200 people were in attendance to watch the game. The United Nations placed the official death toll stemming from the mortar attack at 13, with 133 wounded. At the time it was the deadliest event involving civilians since the imposition of sanctions against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia by the United Nations one year prior.

pages.title: Dobrinja
pages.description: Neighborhood in Sarajevo Canton, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina
pages.abstract: Dobrinja is a neighbourhood in the western outskirts of Sarajevo, part of the municipality of Novi Grad. It is estimated to have a population of 25,063 inhabitants. Its name comes from the short river Dobrinja that flows through it. It is today organised in four local communities. Dobrinja lies just north of Sarajevo International Airport.

pages.title: Sarajevo
pages.abstract: Sarajevo is the capital and largest city of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a population of 275,524 in its administrative limits. The Sarajevo metropolitan area including Sarajevo Canton, East Sarajevo and nearby municipalities is home to 555,210 inhabitants. Located within the greater Sarajevo valley of Bosnia, it is surrounded by the Dinaric Alps and situated along the Miljacka River in the heart of the Balkans, a region of Southern Europe.
